sp.p: I am too deep in your ſecrets for you to dare diſcard me; ſo, I'll have my ſhare.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your—?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ay, my!—My full ſhare. So be ſweet tempered.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And who is to find the money?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And who is to run the riſk?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And who is to be proſecuted for uſury and colluſion.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Caſt perhaps for perjury, whipped, impriſoned, and put in the pillory—You.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: And you to run away with half the profits?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Here's juſtice! Oh, what a damned world do we live in!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Your fortune is made; you muſt now help to make mine.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Here's a villain!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: You muſt, or I tell.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: What will you tell?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: All!—All the uſurious tricks you have practiſed on Mordent: the arts by which you have cheated him of his eſtates, pretending that I am the man; your intention to forecloſe; your neglect in not paying yourſelf intereſt, purpoſely to rob according to law; your plots to ruin Cheveril; all, all!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You will tell all this?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Why you fiend! You ſuperlative villain! You cut-throat!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What the hornie de'el do ye ſtop at? What gars ye ſwither? I'ze haud my whiſht! Yeer confabulation is unco entertaining!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ah! good Mr. Donald! Here is my old friend, Mr. Grime, has, has— (Aſide to Grime.) [You ſee what your villainy has done!] (Aloud.) He is a good-natured ſoul, as you know, [Scoundrel!] and he—I—I—

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ye!—Yas; ye'er a ſweet nut, gin ye war well crackt.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I, I, I was bantering him: trying to, to—[Villain!] but nothing can put him in a paſſion! [Oh, curſe you!] Nothing!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The fient! Wow! But ye'er a pauky Gilligapus?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Perhaps you want our good maſter, Mr. Donald?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Aiblins yeer right, auld Clootie.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: He is gone out. Nothing but a joke, Mr. Donald: nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Noo could I gi' him ſic an a gowf o' the haſfet!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Can I, can my dear friend, Mr. Grime [Oh, you thief!] do you any ſervice?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Haud yeer blether, mon!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Can we oblige you any way in the world?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yas.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: How? How?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tak compaiſſion o' the booels o' yeer brother, Jack Ketch, and be yeer ain hangman!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: There villain! You ſee what you have done!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Is it my fault? I tell you again, you had better be ſweet tempered. I ſhall ſay no more: you know my mind.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Oh that I could poiſon him! (Aloud.) Mr. Grime! Mr. Grime!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Item?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: This quarreling is very fooliſh.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Oh, ho!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: We are neceſſary to each other.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your hand?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: We are friends?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: If you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Well, well— (Aſide.) Damn him! How I hate the dog!—Concerning this Berkſhire mortgage—

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Ay?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You ſhall have twenty per cent. on the premium.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: That won't do!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Thirty!

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: It won't do! Half! The full half!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Hell take him!—Well, well, my dear Grime, the half be it.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Together with my moiety of the thouſand, given with Joanna.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your—? Hem! (Sighs.) You ſhall; you ſhall. Are you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: On theſe conditions.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Where is the deed?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: In that bag.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Mordent is coming. I know he will, for I know he ſhall, ſign. But that is not all.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: This damned Scotchman will aſſuredly betray us to him; and Lady Anne's jointure prevents his being ſo entirely deſtitute, and powerleſs, as is neceſſary,

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: But how is that to be helped?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Eaſily enough. You muſt convey information, to her father and relations, that he has a daughter.

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Nay, but—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Huſh! Here he comes! I will give you my reaſons and inſtructions when we are alone. Where is the deed?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Here, ready. Hem!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is the meaning, Mr. Item, that I ſee that upholſterer, and two other ill-looking followers with him below?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Nay, why aſk me? Why knit your brows at me? Can I coin?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Excuſe me! I am a hunted bull, and butt at friends and foes!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The inſolent fellow inſiſted on taking poſſeſſion; ſo, thinking you would not wiſh Lady Anne to know, I prevailed on him and the officer to remain in the hall, till I could ſpeak to you. If I have done amiſs, ſhew me in what.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, no. I know your zeal. Why will you not advance two thouſand pounds, for that and other immediate purpoſes, and delay ſigning, Mr. Grime? I aſk only a day!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Grime, why will you not?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Don't tell me! Impoſſible, indeed! You ought to conſent; it is your duty: nay, you ſhall conſent!

sp.speaker: Crime.
sp.p: I cannot. Muſt have ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Villain!—Where is the deed?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: So you will not, Mr. Grime? You will not?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I wiſh I could! But I am myſelf a borrower: the money is not my own.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Damn your raſcal hypocriſy! Give me the pen!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Why you will not ſign, ſir! Will you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Peace, fool! Cannot you ſee a wretch on the wheel but that your bones too muſt ach?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ah! It is always thus! I may adviſe, but my advice is never followed!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: "I deliver this as my act and deed." Here, implement of hell! I know your thirſt, blood hound! 'Tis ready mixed deſtruction: take, quaff, and burſt! Begone!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Come, ſir! My good maſter has ſufficient reaſon to be angry with you! It was very unfriendly, ſir, to refuſe. You teach Mr. Mordent what he has to expect. (Aſide.) All is now ſecure!

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter DONALD, looking earneſtly after them.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ha' ye ſigned?—Ha' ye ſigned?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Aſk no queſtions—Yes.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Weel, weel!—Stark deed has nae remeed!—Twa wolves may worry ane ſheep—I kam to tal ye that yeer glib gabbit ſteward, and his compeer, Grime, are too ſcoondrels.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Fool!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I tal ye, they are twa damned villains!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Grime, fellow! Grime! A paltry, gold-loving, ravenous raſcal! But Item?—a worthy man.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: He wordy? That fient? Marcy o' my ſoul! He is the prime cock deel o' the blackeſt pit o' hell! The maliſon curſe catch 'em aw! 'Tis nae ſtick and flow ſax minutes ſin I heard aw their murgullied gab!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Hear?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yas! hear!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What did you hear?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Item himſal confeſs that he had flethered ye of aw yeer eſtates; that Grime is nae mair but his fl • ui • kie; that it is his intantion to forecloſe; that he has wilfully neglacted to pay himſal intereſt, ſo that he may claw ye according tul law; that there ha' been ſ • am deeds; and that a plot is laid to felch maiſter Cheveril of aw his walth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You heard all this?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wi' my ain ears!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Item? Are you ſure you heard this precious miſchief?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: When did Donald tall ye a lie?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! Item? I am glad on't! 'Tis right! 'Tis conſiſtent! 'Tis delightful! Ha, ha, ha!
Abraham's rejected prayer: not one honeſt man. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hoot awa! Nae oneſt? Nor ye nor the black clawed Lucifer himſal canna deny but that Donald is oneſt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Item! Ha, ha, ha! Ineſtimable villain!—And I too? Thought him juſt and good! Oh, Gull! Gull! Gull! Ha, ha, ha! (Recollecting.) Tell Mr. Clement I wiſh to ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Noo the ſteed is ſtolen, ye wad ſteck the door.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh the ſharp fanged wolf! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Mordent! How now? How you look!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am an aſs! A moſt ineffable aſs!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! 'Tis proved upon me!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your mirth is of a ſtrange kind!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The man whom I have truſted through life, ha, ha! ha, he whoſe rigid honeſty—do you mark me? ha, ha, ha! honeſty!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! whoſe honeſty made me ſometimes doubt the truth of the ſelf-evident ſyſtem of evil, ha, ha! he's a raſcal! A double leagued hell dog!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your ſteward?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Item! A deep damnable thorough-paced villain; that can bully, cajole and curſe, fawn, flatter and filch, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be patient.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh I am delighted, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be calm. You knew yourſelf to be in the power of a villain, and 'tis little matter whether his name be Grime or Item.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How? Ha, ha, ha! In a world of raſcality, are not two raſcals better than one?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nay but attend to me. I want your help inſtantly, in Dover-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Dover-ſtreet?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ahey! What's the freak now?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You can have no help of mine.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Indeed but I muſt!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I would not commit an injury on that girl for worlds.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why what conſcientious mummery is this? You neglect your own child, and pretend to intereſt yourſelf for a ſtranger!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If the ſtranger be an angel of light, a beneficent being, why not?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Beneficent! What, in this ſyſtem of evil?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: An exception to the rule! A rare exception?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Like Item?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Hell!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And may not your deſerted daughter be equally an angel?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: May ſhe? If ſhe ſhould—I'll have no concern in the ruin of that girl!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Hark you, Mordent, you are plotting.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: No diſtreſs can cure you of your old propenſities. You mean to trick me of her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: 'Tis evident. Do you not affirm ſhe cannot remain innocent, in the houſe into which ſhe is decoyed?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Granted.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Marriage excepted, which would be madneſs, am I a man to treat her vilely?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not worſe than the malignity of fate ordains.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Pooh! Cant! Cheveril, in the fervor of youth, is lunatic enough rather to marry than loſe her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, ay; he is horn mad to begin his career of wretchedneſs.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And you his guardian, from pretended pity to a ſtranger, will guide and ſpur him to the courſe?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Even ſo it is! Miſchief here, miſchief there; turn which way you will, miſchief!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your word and honour are ſolemnly pledged-If you really wiſh the lovely creature's welfare, would preſerve your ward, and prove your friendſhip and honeſt intentions, you will aid me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, well, I am blind; I am but the tool of deſtiny; ſo be it!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your authority will oblige Mrs. Enfield to yield her to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No; my credit there is on the decline. Stratagem; ſtratagem.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: But how? What?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Convey a diſguiſe to the girl.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And ſo ſhe will eſcape us all!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Eſcape? No, no! Malevolence is the element of man, and I have an apt alacrity: I will inſtruct you. Come this way. Having her ſafe, you may poſt away with her to my commodious houſe in Park-lane. Fear not me! When Belial is buſy, ſhall his progeny be idle?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Maiſter Clement is nae i' the hooſe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No matter— The circle is complete: knaves and fools engender each other; together they make rulers; rulers make laws; laws make villains, and villains ſanctify and perpetuate the uſe of priſons, chains, ropes, racks!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Come, come!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh! What an excellent gull is this image of the gods, this thing called man!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ah! Waes me! This poor laſſie? I canna reſt! I hirple here and gang hilching there, till I'ze e'en ramfeelzed wi'the ripples. I wiſt nae where tul ſpier nieſt. My dool and thole wull be my deeth! I' Gode's name, and wi' aw my hairt; for I'ze recht weary o' life!

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Enter CHEVERIL in great haſte, ſearching.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hoot, man, what is the bang?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: My dear Donald, can you direct me where Mr. Item or Mr. Grime may be found?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Donald diract ye tul ſic on a pair o' ſcoondrels? Father Belzebub! But I wad at anes gar ye o'er catch plague paſtilence and faimine!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! they are both dead and buried, I believe; for they are neither here, nor there, nor any where elſe. Can you tell me where I can borrow a few thouſands?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sir! Do ye tak me for a thief, or a ſteward?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I ſhall go mad—Oh, Donald, I left the moſt angelic girl your eyes ever beheld at a wicked houſe! ſhe muſt be friendleſs and fatherleſs, or ſhe could not have been there.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What's that ye red of angil and fatherleſs?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I am ſure ſhe is innocent. Vile as the houſe is, ſhe is innocent.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Wha? What ſhe? What hooſe?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I can't ſay—I ſaw her firſt in the Green Park.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Green Park?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: She is now at Enfield's—A divine girl! A miracle!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: What? Hoo?—A menzſoo' maikleſs laſs? I' the bloom o' youdith?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Not twenty; yet with the penetration, wit, and underſtanding of the ſeven ſages!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: The Green Pairk? Maircy miſgi' me! Enfield's?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: In Dover-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I ken the place! A hooſe o'hell!—Gin it be—! Quick, Donald, Quick!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What is the matter with the honeſt ſoul? I don't know what ſum that old harridan will require, but I can do nothing without money. I muſt have enough too, for I muſt make ſure. I'll place her in ſafety and ſplendor: ſhe ſhall be my queen!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ah, my dear, dear Item! I am the luckieſt follow on earth! I am in inſtant want of money!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: So am I. I have been in want of it all my life.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You muſt furniſh me with ten thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Ah! I wiſh I could!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sblood, don't ſtand wiſhing, but give me the money!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: If my friend Grime were but here—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and the devil, give me the money! I ſhall loſe her! She'll be gone! I'll make over the ſeventeen thouſand, that is in Mordent's hands! I will by heaven! On the word and honour of a gentleman!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The ſeventeen thouſand?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I will!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: It is true, I have caſh in hand; but not my own.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Zounds! Never mind whoſe it is! Let me have it!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Why, if I could but manage the matter—I am but a poor old man, and it would be a little lift.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Damn your poverty and your cant!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You are ſure you underſtand—the ſeventeen thouſand?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I tell you, yes!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: The riſk will be very great!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Do you doubt my word?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: No, no—But—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Your hand-writing, on a ſtamp, would be a memorandum.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You ſhall have it! Write a receipt for ſeventeen thouſand: I'll ſign it!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.stage: (Searches, takes out an account book, lays it down; then takes out another book, finds a ſtamp, and writes.)
sp.p: Ay, this is the thing. You remember the riſk? Otherwiſe, it might be thought—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Give it me! Give it me! I have no time for hinking!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I muſt borrow to replace it.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Will you come away, and let me have the money? Come, come, man! 'Sdeath will you diſpatch!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Do you know where Mr. Mordent is, ſir?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: No, ſir!
sp.stage: (Cheveril burries Item off, who puts up his receipt in one book, but forgets the other, that he laid down on the table.)

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent has aſked for me, and unfortunately I cannot find him. I fear he has ſigned the mortgage. Oh this uncle! Never was ſituation ſo excruciating as mine. Muſt I caſt off all ties of blood, become his accuſer, and, as the world would call it, betray my benefactor? Beſide, what have I to reveal? My fears and my ſuſpicions. Unconnected facts, that can alarm but not relieve. And who is it that I ſhould thus impotently accuſe? My own uncle. (Sees the book.) Hah! What have we here? As I live, his private account book! The very thing he ſo carefully has concealed from all inſpection! What ſhall I do? Deliver it to Mordent? What may be the conſequences? Diſgrace, infamy, and—! Dreadful thought! I muſt not be raſh.—Hark! He's here! I muſt conſider well.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: Re-enter ITEM and CHEVERIL. Item with his hair on end, frightened; runs up to the table, looks over it, under it, and every where.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You ſee, there is no book there!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I am certain I had it in my hand!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: We have not quitted the room a minute! Nobody can have been here ſince!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: We leſt my nephew here.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, if he have it, 'tis ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I don't know that! I don't know that! If I have loſt it, I ſhall never ſleep again!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come away! You have it ſomewhere, locked up ſafe.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: No! I laid it down here! I am poſitive of it!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Nay, but you ſee that is impoſſible! Come, come!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: If it be gone, I ſhall go mad!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Is it ſo valuable?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.stage: (Still ſearching his pockets, the table, and the chamber.)
sp.p: I would not loſe it for all I am worth in the world!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come, come— (Elbowing him but not rudely, at firſt to the door.) What did it contain?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My ſoul! My ſecrets!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, it certainly is not here! You muſt go! You ſhall go! I'll indemnify you!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You can't!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I tell you, I will! (Puſhing him off.) It is in your own room.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I hope ſo! I hope ſo! (Turning back.) But my heart miſgives me! Oh lord! I'm undone!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Will you go?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I am wretched!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You won't!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I am ruined!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Will you, or—?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I'm loſt! I'm dead! I'm—!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Furies and fire, begone!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Cheveril! (Runs over to the door.) Mr. Cheveril!—'Tis impoſſible to ſtop him! But no matter; the plan cannot fail: Lennox by this time has her ſafe. Why ay! I have adviſed! I have plotted, I have aided! And in what? Why the ruin of an innocent; who, while I looked and liſtened to her, I would have loſt my life to defend? Why was man endowed with thought? It breeds but confuſion! Fools have called it the gift of gods, wiſe men know it to be the medium of miſery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar,
sp.p: My lady, ſir, deſires to know if ſhe may have the honour to ſee you!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is the matter now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Oh! as to that, let my lady ſpeak! I have got ill-blood enough, becauſe I would not take ſomebody's part. But that is all over.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is over?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I have told my lady, often and often, how a gentleman's proud ſpirit might be brought down: but ſhe would never liſten to my conſultation before.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Before?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: For ſaid I, my lady, you would be as merry as May, if you would but pluck up a ſpirit to take the Earl's advice, and leave all baſe ſeducers to their own courſe!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Yes, I did! I ſhould be no woman, if I did not take part with my ſeet! So we are all ready for moving, ſeeing as we are reſolved. For, ſaid I, if he ſhould fall at my feet and cry his eyes out; I would not hear a word!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Not but I have as tender a heart as another. But then, I would ſooner break his heart than my own!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What does this inſolent gabble mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Not but I have as tender a heart as another. But then, I would ſooner break his heart than my own!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What does this inſolent gabble mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Why it means that any lady is coming to take her leave; and that then we ſhall be gone; and then it will be ſeen who will have moſt cauſe to repent.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I am ſure if I could have made folks happy, I would have done it with all my heart and ſoul! But the ſecret is out at laſt; and all is ſettled. Not but, for all I'm ſo glad, I can't ſay but I'm ſorry in the main! for I'm ſure ſome folks will be miſerable enough! and, though they richly deſerve it, one can't help feeling for them, in ones heart. And ſo, ſir, as perhaps I ſhall never ſee you no more, God bleſs you, and mend you!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent, I am driven upon an agonizing taſk, which a too painful ſenſe of duty only could oblige me to execute.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Proceed, Madam; apologies, for feeling or for inflicting pain, are quite unneceſſary!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Forgive me! Would it were to be avoided!—You have a daughter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Whence gain you that intelligence!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: From the Earl of Oldereſt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And what is his authority?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I know not. But I, it ſeems, have innocently been the cauſe that ſhe is diſowned and abandoned. Of ſuch an act I cannot knowingly conſent to be a moment guilty. The fatal period is come! that ſeparation which I ſo much have dreaded, is inevitable!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And you ſupport your fate with patience.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Cruel man! do I deſerve this parting reproach?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You deſerve? Who ſhall dare inſinuate it?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Happy days and paſt endearments ruſh upon my mind with ſenſations unutterable?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I know! I know!—I am the vileſt of men!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Far from ſaying, far from thinking ſo, I take my full ſhare of blame. How do I know that the fault is not wholly mine?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Madam I—I—I requeſt I may be tortured by any thing but your candor.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I know I have loſt the envied art of making myſelf intelligible to your feelings! And how? You once were happy, tender, and pro •• to ſmile at every look and word of mine! Of what fatal errors have I been guilty, that ſhould have wrought this change?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, exquiſite! Continue! my nerves are ſtrung!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p:
To deſpair of recovering thoſe ineſtimable bleſſings was quite ſufficient! But to be the cauſe of baniſhing a child from a father's arms and heart? to caſt it an orphan on a tempeſtuous world? No! whatever
my other miſtakes may have been, of that no tongue ſhall accuſe me!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Right! let the guilt be all my own!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And now, I have one laſt requeſt to make; which I conjure you, by all our former affection not to deny!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To aſk favours, where there is neither the power to grant nor the deſire to be thanked, is fruitleſs,

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: I am but too well acquainted with the ſtate of your affairs.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A humane motive for parting!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: The ſettlements you have made on me, in our early days of love, were ample. In the ſincerity of affection, I vowed, if ever they ſhould be neceſſary to your happineſs, that moment they ſhould again be yours.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Pardon and endure this proof of my fidelity! The deeds are now in Mr. Clement's poſſeſſion: he will reſtore them to you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Never!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Stop! Beware of raſhneſs! You are a father, and have a father's ſacred duties to fulfil. Take home your daughter: make her what amends you can for the deſertion of a parent's love.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis too much! Scorpions could not ſting like this!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: On this laſt occaſion, ſuffer a gleam of former kindneſs once more to warm your boſom. Money is a poor vehicle, for the affections of the ſoul! a contemptible token of the love I have borne you! but, ſuch as it is, for that love's ſake, give it welcome! A cold adieu I cannot take! It freezes my very heart! From my ſoul, I ever have loved, and ever ſhall love! Had I a heaven of happineſs to beſtow, would you but deign to accept it from me, it ſhould be yours.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, ſo! ſo! ſo!—It rages! it burſts! it is complete! Let fate or fiends increaſe the miſery, if they can!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: It's paſt! It's aw o'er! My forebodings are foofilled!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have you not found her yet?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Yes, yes! I have foond her!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have you? Where?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I'ze noo indeed a raſca' go-between! (Horror.) But what are ye?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You ſay you have found her?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: She is gone! She is ruined! Ye're a wratch: the moſt meeſerable o' wratches!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Tormenting demon! What? Who?—Where have you been?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: To Dover-ſtreet!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Dover—?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Tul the elritch limmer Enfield.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: I was too late! A maiſter ſcoondrel, e'en as wecked as her ain father, had decoyed her intul his net!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Decoyed?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Lennox! Yeer friend; veer crony!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: From Enfield's!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Ha' not I toud ye?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Lennox? Dover-ſtreet? Joanna?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hear it, gin ye can, and live! Joanna! yeer child! Yeer guilcleſs Joanna!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Miſery of Hell! And was that Joanna? That my child? Celeſtial creature! And I the pit-digger!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Sir!—Sir!—Maiſter!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I the pander? I caſt her ſhrieking on the bed of infamy, and chain her in the arms of luſt? Her father to do this?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p:
Maiſter!—Dear Maiſter!—Maiſter Mordent! Dear Maiſter Mordent! Speak! I'ze forgi' ye! Why
maiſter! I'ze pray for ye! I'ze die for ye! I'ze forgi' ye!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.stage: (Starting from a profound trance of deſpondency.)
sp.p: Fly! Summon the ſervants! Arm yourselves! follow me to Park Lane!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: William! Sandy! Jock!

sp.speaker: MORDENT.
sp.p: WE are now in private.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I am glad we are.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And now, Sir, I inſiſt on a clear and explicit anſwer. Where have you lodged Joanna?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, Where have you lodged Joanna?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Lennox, I will not be trifled with! where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Nor will I be trifled with, Mr. Mordent: I ſay where is ſhe? The contrivance was your own! I know you! The moment you ſet your eyes on her you began your curſed plots, to ſecure her for yourſelf; and, when you found I would not give her up at your perſuaſion, you put them in practice while you treacherouſly pretended to ſcure her to me.—I tell you, I know you.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: This will not ſerve, ſir, it is all evaſion.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Ay, ſir, it is evaſion! cunning, baſe, damned evaſion! and I affirm ſhe is in your poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Lennox, I am at this moment a determined and deſperate man, and muſt be anſwered—Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Sir, I am as determined and as deſperate as yourſelf, and I ſay, where is ſhe? For you alone can tell?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Falſe?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay, falſe!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: He is the falſeſt of the falſe that dares whiſper ſuch a word!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Hark you, ſir, I underſtand your meaning, and came purpoſely provided. (Draws a pair of piſtols.) Take your choice. They are loaded.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Oh, with all my heart! (Preſents at ſome paces diſtant.) Come, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nigher!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: As nigh as you pleaſe!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Foot to foot!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Muzzle to muzzle!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why don't you fire?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why don't you unlock your piſtol?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: There!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Why do you turn it out of the line?— (Drops his arm. Pauſe,) I ſee your intention, Mordent! You are tired of life, and want me to murder you!—Damn it, man, that is not treating your friend like a friend!—Kill me if you will, but don't make me your aſſaſſin!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, kill me, or tell me where you have lodged the wretched girl.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Fiends ſeize me if I have lodged her any where, or know what is become of her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Your behaviour tells me you are ſincere, and to convince you at once that I am no leſs ſo, know—ſhe is my daughter!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The honeſt indefatigable Donald diſcovered her at Enfield's!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Murder my friend, and debauch his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: We are ſad fellows.— (They pauſe, and gradually recover from the deep paſſion with which they were mutually ſeized.) Again and again, 'tis a vile world.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I'll ſeek it through with you to find her.—Forgive me?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Would I could forgive myſelf!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: But it ſeems then ſhe has eſcaped, and is perhaps in ſafety.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh that ſhe were!—Donald uſed to meet her here, in the Green Park, about this time of the evening. (Liſtens,) I hear the ſound of feet. (Looks.) 'Tis not a woman. Let us retire among the trees, and keep on the watch.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: She is not here—ſhe is gone! For ever gone—gone—gone! I ſhall never more ſet eyes on her! I'll fire that infernal Dover-ſtreet!—I'll piſtol Lennox!—I may perambulate here till doomſday, and to no purpoſe. She would have been here had ſhe been free. Ay, ay, ſhe is in thraldom; perhaps in the very gripe of vice'—Furies!—Lennox is a liar!—I'll cut his throat!—I'll hack him piece-meal!—I'll have her, or I'll have his heart!

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter JOANNA in men's cloaths. CHEVERIL ſeen walking among the trees.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Whither ſhall I run?—Where ſhall I hide? How fly the purſuits of wicked men, and women ſtill more depraved? I have neither houſe, home, nor friend on earth; and the fortitude that can patiently endure is my only reſource. What then?—Have I not eſcaped the dens of vice!—Oh happineſs!—I have!—I have! And rather than venture in them again, welcome hunger, welcome cold, welcome the bare ground, the biting air, and the ſociety of brute beaſts.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: What can that youth want? Why is he watching here?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: As I live the young gentleman I ſaw this morning! What reaſon can he have for being in this place?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: He eyes me with curioſity.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: His intentions ſeemed good, for he firſt warned me againſt that wicked woman.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Who can ſay, he may know her? He is a ſmart, handſome, dapper fellow: I don't like him.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I am not now confined by walls and bolts;—there can be no danger.—I'll ſpeak.—Pray, ſir—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well, ſir?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Have you ſeen a young perſon—?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: A lady—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: With blue eyes, auburn hair, aquiline noſe, ivory teeth, carnation lips, raviſhing mouth, enchanting neck, a form divine, and an angel face?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Have you ſeen her?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with that lady?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I am acquainted with a lady, but not an angel.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ah! then it is not her. (Jealous) Perhaps you are her—her lover?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Humph—I—I love her.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You do! (Aſide.) I'll be the death of him!—And ſhe loves you?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Why—Yes.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I'll put an end to him!—Are you married?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You—you mean to marry her?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Is ſhe then loſt to virtue?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Who dare ſuppoſe it?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Ay! who dare? I'll cut the villain's throat that dares!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: She has endured inſult, conſtraint, and violence; but not guilt.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Guilt? No; not wilful guilt: impoſſible! But then—Is ſhe ſafe? Is ſhe ſafe?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Diſowned by her family, expoſed to the ſnares of vice, houſeleſs, hopeleſs, not daring to approach the wicked haunts of men, ſhe wanders forlorn and deſolate, willing to ſuffer, diſdaining to complain.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Tell me where! I will reſcue, defend, protect, cheriſh, love, adore, die for her!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Is your heart pure? Have you no ſelfiſh diſhoneſt purpoſes?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: How came you to imagine, ſir, that I or any man durſt couple her and diſhoneſty, even in a thought?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Meet me here to-morrow at ten.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee her.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: See her! Shall I?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: You ſhall.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: My dear friend! (Catching her in his arms.) I'll make your fortune!—At nine?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Ten.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Could not I ſee her to-night?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: To-morrow Joanna will meet you.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna? Is that her dear name?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Delightful ſound! The ſweet Joanna! The divine Joanna! My heart's beſt blood is not ſo precious as Joanna!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: But pray where do you live?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna!—In Portland-Place.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Your name?

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna!—Cheveril: Hans Cheveril.—Joanna!—Be ſure you don't forget.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I'll be punctual.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Who's here

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna!—At eight did not you ſay?—Where is he gone?—Sir! Sir!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I heard the name repeated! (Aloud.) Who is it here that knows Joanna?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Sir! Do you! Well, and what? Where?—Is ſhe ſafe?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But where, Sir, where?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: 'Tis Mr. Mordent! (Aloud.) Why do you enquire?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, Sir, do not torment me by delay, but tell me where ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I muſt not.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But, Sir, I ſay you muſt, and ſhall!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Sir, you miſtake, if you ſuppoſe menaces can prevail.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Excuſe me! I would give my right hand to know what it appears you can tell.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I can tell nothing, 'till I am firſt made acquainted with your true motives.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And will you inform me then?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Provided I am certain of their purity.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Know then that I pant for a ſight of her once more, to do her the little juſtice that is yet in my power. Know, the wrongs ſhe has received from me are irreparable, vile, ſuch as could not have happened but in this worſt of worlds! Know that I, her natural guardian, have been her actual perſecutor; that I drove her to the abode of infamy; that I became the agent of her ruin, the plotter againſt her chaſtity; and that, when I had ſet the engines of darkneſs and hell at work to enſure her everlaſting wretchedneſs, I then diſcovered [With horror.] ſhe was my daughter!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Sir!—Your daughter!—You? You my father?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.stage: (Falling at his feet and ſnatching his hand)

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Can it be?—My child—? —My Joanna? (Eagerly raiſing and regarding her again.) It is! It is!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My child! And innocent?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: As your own wiſhes; or the word father ſhould never have eſcaped my lips! This dreſs was the diſguiſe conveyed to me, by which I effected my eſcape. I can ſuffer any thing but diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A father? Oh!—I do not deſerve thee! I do not deſerve thee! (Gazing rapturouſly.) Once again, let me ſold thee to my heart!

sp.speaker: Len
sp.p: Zounds, ſir!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: I inſiſt, ſir!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: I hear voices.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Oh for ſwords, daggers, piſtols!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: This way!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Confound your impertinent freaks; they have ſtopped my mouth this half hour; I would have told you all I knew inſtantly, but for your inſulting paſſion!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Did not you ſay you would not tell me where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: I ſaid I could not.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why there now.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: But I ſuſpect I can tell more at preſent, if you will but hear.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, then, why don't you?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Will you be ſilent?—I had a glimpſe of Mordent this moment, in converſation with a youth.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: It was the identical dreſs I ſent as a diſguiſe to Joanna.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: And I ſuſpect that very youth to be Joanna herſelf.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: By heaven, and ſo it is! (Anger and fear.) In the poſſeſſion of Mordent?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be patient—there is a ſecret—His claims ſuperſede all others.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: His claim!—By every power of heaven and hell—

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Be patient I tell you;—ſhe is his daughter!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna? my ſweet Joanna? his daughter?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Even ſo.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: His daughter? Hurrah! My dear Lennox! (Hugs him in his arms.) Hurrah! (In extacy.) Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Hurrah! His daughter? Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!

div.head: SCENE VI. The Houſe of MORDENT.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Are you ſure it was Mr. Mordent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I tell, you, ſir, I was on the watch, and opened the door myſelf. Take care, my dear, ſaid he, to the ſham gentleman lady; and handed her in as lovingly!—The monſter!—My lady is bewitched!—She is fabricated!—She can't quit the houſe. I am ſure he muſt have nailed an inviſible horſe-ſhoe to the threſhold!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But how do you know this pretended youth to be a woman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: Did not I hear? I held the candle full flare in her face; it was a perfect picter! I never ſaw the like.—So ſhe is to be brought home, truly!—Such magnanimous impudence! But I'll go to my lady.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Be cautious: you may do miſchief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sar.
sp.p: I don't care! I am reſolved to ſtabilate and confound facts. So then, having a ſufficient dearth of proofs, we ſhall ſail off in the charut; and be properly received by the Earl, the Viſcount, and the Biſhop; and be ſquired into the hall; and be kiſſed for joy; and ſhall ſwim up ſtairs into the boſom of the family.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Dear Clement, have you ſeen Mr. Mordent?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No:—I am in ſearch of him, on affairs of the utmost importance.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No leſs than the recovery or total loſs of his mortgaged lands.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I am in great need of advice, and ſhould be glad to conſult you.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Conſult!—'Sdeath, man, I am in a hurry! I cannot reſt till I have found him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, but on the deciſion of the moment his ruin or ſafety depends.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Indeed! If ſo, my impatience muſt wait. What is it?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I hear footſteps.—This way.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Yes, dear girl, your rare endowments ſurpaſs my hopes; and, convinced as I am that beauty is deſtructive, and wiſdom impotent, I joy to find you thus adorned.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Wait to know me better. I fear you ſhould prize me above my worth.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: How ſhall I reward it? Fool that I am, madman that I have been.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: This is my rich reward!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have told you in part my deſperate ſituation. If Grime would but give honeſt evidence—But of that there is little hope.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My greateſt fear ariſes from what you have ſaid of Lady Anne. I muſt not, will not be the cauſe of ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let me do her juſtice: She is a miracle of forbearance. I have hated and ſpurned at the kindneſs I did not deſerve. Her perſeverance in good has been my aſtoniſhment and my torture.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh that I could ſee you reconciled! Oh that I could gain the love of ſuch a lady!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Of that, ſweet girl, you are certain. Lennox is with her, and by this ſhe knows your ſtory; and I am ſure adores your virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I hear her.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Oh! noble girl! (Runs and embraces Joanna.) Forgive this rude tumult of affection, which I cannot reſtrain.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Mr. Mordent, you are now a million fold more dear to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I cannot bear it!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Will you be my daughter?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, madam!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Adverſity I could endure, but this unhoped-for tide of bleſſings overpowers me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, how I hate myſelf!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: And why?—Can you be ignorant of the virtuous ſtruggles which have cauſed the conflict you have felt? The ſtrength of theſe ſenſations ſhew how fitted you are to be great and good.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: To be a—I dare not think!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Indeed you are wrong. Had I not been guilty of a thouſand errors, you never would have had occaſion for this ſelf reproach. Like cowards, we both have ſhunned inquiry. Let us be more courageous; let us affectionately communicate our mutual miſtakes, and while we examine we ſhall correct the mind, expand the heart, and render ourſelves dear to each other, and beneficent to the whole world.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh ſhame, ſhame!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: Nay, my love—

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My dear father!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, well, I will endure exiſtence a little longer, if it be but to hate myſelf.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: My life! my ſoul! my precious Joanna!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: They will perſuade me preſently that happineſs is poſſible!—You have cauſe, child, to thank Mr. Cheveril?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: Oh, yes! he has a heart of the nobleſt ſtamp.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Ay! every body right! All angels! except myſelf: I am caſt into the ſhade; a kind of demon, grinning in the dark!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come, come, guardian, diſmiſs theſe ſombre familiars, they have plagued you long enough. Clement is in eager ſearch of you, to communicate ſecrets of the utmoſt importance concerning his uncle.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: The villain!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Yes:—he is below, half diſtracted, foaming with rage, and accuſing every ſervant in the houſe with having ſtolen his book! I hear him—Pray keep back! My ſweet Joanna, but for a moment.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: 'Tis gone! 'tis loſt! I am undone! I am murdered! I am betrayed!—I ſhall be proſecuted, pilloried, fined, caſt in damages, obliged to pay all, to refund all, to relinquiſh all!—all—all—all! I'll hang myſelf!—I'll drown myſelf!—I'll cut my throat!—Mordent has got it!—All my ſecrets, all my projects, all my rogueries,—paſt, preſent, and to come!—Oh that I had never been born!—Oh that—

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Have you ſeen my book?—Give it me!—Where is my book?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What book?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My account book! my ſecrets! myſelf! my ſoul! my heart's blood! (Seizes Clement's coat laps, and ſearches.) I have it—'tis here—I feel it!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, 'tis here. Be pacified.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I won't! I won't! I'll have it! Give it me! I'll ſwear a robbery! I'll have you hanged!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.stage: (Takes a book ſealed up out of his pocket.)
sp.p: This book, ſir, I conſider as a ſacred truſt; and part with it to you I muſt not.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: You ſhall part with it, villain! You ſhall! I'll have your ſoul! 'Tis mine! I'll have your heart! 'Tis mine! I will have it! I will have it! I will have it!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You ſhall have heart, life, and ſoul firſt!

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: My dear nephew! My good boy! My kind Clement! I'll ſupply all your wants! I'll pay all your debts! I'll never deny any thing you aſk! I'll make you my heir!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: You are the agent of Mr. Mordent, whom I fear you have deeply wronged, I have a painful duty to perform; but juſtice muſt be obeyed: nothing muſt or ſhall bribe me to betray an injured man.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: I'll give you ten thouſand pounds! I'll give you twenty! I'll give you fifty! Would you rob and ruin your uncle? Would you put him in the pillory? Would you ſee him hanged? (Falls upon him again.) Villain! I will have it! 'Tis mine! I will! I will! Thieves! Robbers! Murder! Fire!

div.head: SCENE the laſt.
div.stage: Enter Mr. MORDENT, Lady ANNE, LENNOX, CLEMENT, GRIME, DONALD, JOANNA, and CHEVERIL.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am glad Mr. Item, that your inattention and your nephew's inflexible honeſty have afforded me the means of doing myſelf juſtice: that is all I require.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Here is double teſtimony: your hand-writing and your agent.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Have you impeached then?

sp.speaker: Grime.
sp.p: I am a villain, a raſcal, a cut throat!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Mr. Clement, your worth and virtue are beyond my praiſe.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: If my conduct eſcape cenſure, it is more than I expect.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If it meet not retribution, all ſenſe of juſtice is loſt. Donald!

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: My watchful guide! My never failing friend!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Your hand, old boy! You and I muſt ſettle accounts. I am I know not how many ſcore pounds a year in your debt.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What then am I?

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: And I?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Hoot awa! Gin ye wad pay Donald, it mun nae be wi' yeer dirty ſiller; it mun be wi' yeer affactions.

sp.speaker: Joanna.
sp.p: True, my noble protector!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: Why ay, noo! That's a receipt in foo?—It makes my hairt gi' ſic an a bang!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Honeſt worthy ſoul. And now to reconcile—

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Come, come; make no ſpeeches. I'll ſettle the buſineſs. I am the proper perſon. I have eight thouſand a year, and ten thouſand in my pocket—Ten? (To Item.) Is it ten or ſeventeen?

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Seventeen!

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Joanna ſhall be my queen of joy, pleaſure, and happineſs. Honeſty, here, ſhall ſettle all his ill-gotten gains on his nephew: Lennox, as a bachelor's pennance, ſhall marry his houſemaid: You, Guardian, ſhall change your ſyſtem of evil for practical good: Lady Anne ſhall become more patient and kind—if ſhe know how: and old Moloch (To Grime.) ſhall go hang himſelf.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.p: Spoken like an oracle.

sp.speaker: Chev.
sp.p: Why then, toſs up your caps, farewel to folly, long life to one and twenty, and mirth, health, and happineſs to all!

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.p: How ſtrange are the viciſſitudes of fortune! With what gloom was the dawn overcaſt! How have the ſtorms of this memorable day riſen, and increaſed even to horror! And now how bright the proſpect; and how glowing the hope that it excites! Ceeriſh it, kind friends, with your ſmiles: and, in the gentle ſlumbers of the night, let us joyfully dream that we ſtill merit, and ſtill obtain, your willing favour.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Mrs. POPE, Miſs WALLIS, and Mrs. MATTOCKS come forward.

sp.speaker: Mrs. POPE.
sp.l: AND now, thrice gentle friends, our plotting ended,
We hope you're pleas'd—at leaſt not much offended?
Surely, you'll own it was a little moving,
To ſee a modern wife ſo very loving!
Who deems the marriage vow a thing expedient!
And is at once meek! faithful! and obedient!
Such whims were common in the golden age:
And ſtill they may be met with—on the ſtage:
But grant they now are falſe, paſt contradiction,
We hope they yet may be endur'd—in fiction.

sp.speaker: Miſs WALLIS.
sp.l: You've heard that good Queen Befs had maids of honour;
Whoſe courtly trade it was to wait upon her;
To quaff brown ſtout, yet not be overtaken,
Breakfaſt on beef, and ſup on eggs and bacon?
In thoſe ſtrange days, I can't ſay what might happen!
Virtue might, then, be thought the woman's weapon!
But daughters now like me, whate'er we feign,
No where exiſt; but in a poet's brain!
Such blunders are too groſs! No ſoul can brook 'em!
And yet I wiſh, for once, you'd overlook 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. MATTOCKS.
sp.l: Poor Man! He's mad! An heir of one and twenty,
With frolicks, freaks, and pounds and paſſions plenty,
Who, being told where he may purchaſe beauty,
Begins to cant of conſcience, love, and duty?
Was ſuch ſtuff ever heard? Ye ſprigs of faſhion,
Say, is it thus you treat the tender paſſion?
'Ere ſuch ſhall come, and prophets ſhall ſpeak truth!
Yet, put him not in poet's purgatory;
For, ſhould you damn him, we ſhall all be ſorry.

sp.speaker: Miſs WALLIS.
sp.p: Then be ſweet temper'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. MATTOCKS.
sp.p: Grant the man his cauſe!

sp.speaker: Mrs. POPE.
sp.p: And once more make us bleſt in your applauſe.
